key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal molecular and protein information with per-sample out-of-distribution uncertainty estimates to substantially improve binding affinity prediction in polypharmacology settings.
problem_solved: Accurately predicting how a compound binds to many different protein targets is hard when test compounds or targets differ from training data; existing models often give overconfident, uncalibrated predictions that hurt decision-making in drug discovery.
method: Fuse multimodal inputs (e.g., chemical representations and protein descriptors/structures) into a unified model to capture interaction mechanics across ligand–target pairs.
Estimate individual (per-example) uncertainty that is aware of out-of-distribution (OOD) conditions so predictions can be calibrated and flagged when unreliable.
Use uncertainty-aware training and evaluation to improve fidelity of binding affinity predictions and prioritize safer, more actionable predictions for polypharmacology.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners with a practical framework for producing more reliable, decision-ready binding affinity predictions and for identifying when model outputs are untrustworthy — accelerating hit prioritization and reducing costly experimental follow-up.
visual_elements: Model architecture diagram showing multimodal inputs (molecule + protein) merging into an interaction encoder and uncertainty module
Scatter plot of predicted vs. experimental binding affinities colored by per-sample uncertainty (low → high) to show calibration
Bar or calibration curve comparing error rates for in-distribution vs. OOD examples with and without uncertainty-aware modeling
Network diagram illustrating polypharmacology: a compound connected to multiple protein nodes with edge thickness or color indicating predicted affinity and uncertainty
paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
